reviewText:
Zombi is, as many of you already know, an enhanced port of ZombiU, a launch title for the WiiU. While it was a pretty good game overall, it wasn't really well-received, and I always thought that was unfortunate because I enjoyed it a lot.

Zombi is a game that puts a big emphasis on death, and features two different gameplay modes to accomodate this. The first Standard mode, which is more like the death mechanic used in the Souls series. When you first start the game you get a random character with a quick explanation of his or her name and occupation, and that's your character. A single zombie bite will kill you, though they usually attack through swipes unless they catch you off guard. If you die in this mode, your character is permanently killed, and a new survivor arrives at the safe house for you to play as. If you can get to your old survivor without dying, you can regain your items, but if you die again, all of the items from the original survivor are gone, barring the ones that can't be taken from you like the cricket bat and flashlight. In the second mode, Survival, more inspired by rogue-likes, the stakes are even higher and if you die then that's it; the game's over.

The two options each come with a Chicken" difficulty setting that makes them easier

reviewText:
While I've had a lot of fun with this title, there are just enough cons about it so that I just cannot recommend it. But let's start of with the pros:

+ Very well balanced weapons
+ Great melee combat (Not like the all over the place-crap in Dead Island)
+ There's a lot of variety in the missions
+ The scanning tool makes for an interesting gameplay
+ No stamina system for attacks

But as I've said, there is a lot of negative aspects about this game, so here we go:

- The level design is boring. Also, many places look exactly the same.
- The game is WAY too short, even for 20 bucks.
- There are just 5-6 enemy types which don't even behave very differently
- Crashes occur on multiple occassions and Ubisoft doesn't seem to care enough to fix those
- No autosaving, meaning that everything's lost once the game crashes
- Boring fast travel system and small world
- Characters are not even close to being well-developed
- Even though there are zombies, the world feels very empty
- No advanced graphics settings

Overall, this is just a rushed port to make some money. I'd still recommend to grab it in a sale for 5 bucks or so, but please, for the love of god, do not buy this at full price.

I played this game on the Wii U for days, I think, and I can't believe it's finally coming to Steam.
To this day, ZombiU is one of my favorite Wii U games, and one of my favorite zombie games of all time.  The survival-horror elements are really and well-implemented, especially because of the death system the game implements.  If you die, you lose your stuff, and have to get it back.  If you die again before reclaiming it, it's gone.  For good.
Having played both versions now, I have to say, although I still prefer the Wii U version, this is a very accurate recereation of it.  I do wish, just a little, that the multiplayer was still a part of it, as I really liked that, too, and I think they could make it work on PC, but unfortunately it was cut.  That, really, is my main gripe.
Although the game's a bit short, and the ending is dissapointing (unless they've changed it for the PC version), the game has quite a bit of challenging, especially if you play survival mode.
This game is a must-have for fans of the survival-horror genre.  Although it isn't adding much new to the genre, it's still a lot of fun to play, and for $20, it's a great deal.
I'd give it an 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Let's be honest, Zombi is just a quick cash grab from Ubisoft to make some dosh this summer, so you should not expect an amazing port. So what did they do? They took a WiiU exclusive game and ported it to others platforms. Basically, you are playing a zombie game where death is permanent. You die, you loose all the stuff your character was holding and you start from scratch with another character. It's a cool concept, it reminds me of Diablo II where if you died, you were starting from scratch and you had to get your stuff back.

The gameplay consists of looting areas, fighting the zeds with your melee weapons or fire weapons, and of course, do the quests your being told to do. Talking about weapons, there is a nice variety of weapons like MP5,UMP, AK, silenced pisol, pistol, shotgun, M1014, crossbow etc... . To help you in your looting you have a scanner that tells you the locations of loot in your area, reveals code for numpads, reveals if an infected has some loot on it. That feature on WiiU was done with the gamepad, but here it's everything on one screen, just like all the gamepad feature in fact. Since we have no wiiu gamepad, all the stuff is done via one screen, same goes for the map that is on the bottom right corner. So when it comes to immersion and all, you could say that the WiiU is superior in that point. The main issue about the gameplay is that we have WAY TOO MUCH ressources. Seriously, you have a really big arsenal of ammunition.  There are so much ammunitions to find, that I found myself just not caring in some areas at some point because I knew in the safehouse I had enough to keep feeding my trigger friendly fingers.

The story is pretty much meh. Another zombie infection where you'll try to find a cure or a vaccine and get the hell ouf of there with the same old clichés that you've seen a hundred times either in moves or in other games. I guess the cool thing in the story is that you get to see a zombie eating a child. The main story is kinda short as well. I've completed the game in 9 hours and I could have beaten it faster if I didn't have so much trouble to find the 7 Dee's letters. Talking about those letters, they are just there to do some padding and try to increase the length of the game artificially. At least, if you are a good explorer, you can get some of them in advance on your first run and won't have to do too much back tracking.

The port in itself isn't very exceptionnal. You got FOV settings, resolutions, vsync and that is it. At least, the frame rate is completely uncapped. Overall, the game is running fine, but there are some areas where the frame rate will just drop from 125fps to 45fps in just a matter of second. I didn't experienced frame drops too much but it was happening often in the roof of the London Tower and the turret areas near Buckingam. The game isn't looking very good and it has some physics issues with the zombies.

Overall, this game is okay, I had fun playing it and I'll probably go back to it at some point.

I want to like it. I really do. It feels like a good game is there, somewhere, but it's lost in all the fluff. The game's biggest feature is that you play as a new survivor and your old one is zombified with all your old gear, but I've only died once and it was to an environmental feature, not zombies (A doorway on fire looked fine on the other side, so I dashed through it and instantly died).

I wanted to play the game, but dropping the coin on a WiiU for a launch title was not appealing. At least I know the quality of the game now.

PRO:
Survivors becoming skilled with weaponry is a good incentive not to die
Zombies hiding around doorways and pretending to be dead does add a decent amount of tension
Scoring headshots feel satisfying
Certain weapons have enough ammo to carry you for a while (Special mention: Crossbow bolts are retrievable)


CON:
Touted as a survival horror game, the only legitimately scary part of the game is brief and never mentioned again
Very little is explained, and what is does not deserve mention
Too many different weapon categories relying on different ammo types - Do we need a pistol and a magnum? In a game about inventory management, there's a lot of useless noise. (Looking at you, planks)
Secret areas were a bit of a disappointment - Usually it's not about being clever, but finding the right item to come back and unlock them.
It's pretty hard to die. Most - If not all - Encounters can be completed just by kiting the zombies backwards in a large circle and clubbing the leader over the head.
Despite the game early on telling you to do it, there's little point in barricading doors.
Characters you play as are very disposable - We're told a name, job, age, and are shown their appearance, but they add nothing to the story. It'd be more interesting if there was at least a blurb of randomized backstory and some skills/deficencies already existing for survival skills.
Game is linear. You can wander around for supplies, but generally they're scraps you might use up during a scuffle while you're out anyway. There's no zones just for exploring.
Items in your secure safehouse disappear, and your storage has limited inventory. This might be a gameplay feature, but it's just a weird decision.

It's just so close to being good. It needs to offer a more open world experience - If you had to find food and water supplies for other survivors, or if there wasn't always just one route to every step in the story, it would have been a much richer experience. Instead, it's a straightforward shooter with an emphasis on melee. Get it on sale if you must, but there's no meat here and no replayability.

Fast forward to present times, the world is in chaos and probably John Dee is rolling in his grave saying “I told you so.” Now, with no means of developing a cure, some people turn to the lost writings of John Dee as their only salvation. They believe that the only way to stop this disease is to locate the writings of John Dee and produce the “panacea” that is described in his manuscripts. Guess what? It’s our job as the main character to find these writings and at same time, ensure that we survive long enough to see the next day.

In my 10+ hours worth of gameplay, I only crashed 3 times at a certain part, which I believe is a game breaking bug. I’ve read in the forums that some people are crashing at the intro scene and that is a rather unfortunate.

See here:  Nursery Crash

I have no complaints with the graphics because the game is quite pleasant to look at. I’m not really playing it for the graphics so I can’t complain. There is also that pesky Uplay DRM so if you don’t want to deal with Uplay, do not buy the game.

To tell you the truth, Zombi offers nothing new to the table, in terms of a survival horror zombie game. You kill zombies, loot, scour for supplies, and kill some more zombies. You know, the usually Friday night. The several locations we visit in Zombi tend to be small but there are hidden nooks and crannies to be explored and shortcuts to open (God, I love shortcuts). Our pad, a multipurpose scanner that can hack doors, check for hostiles and useful items, and reveal hidden messages, is our best friend and I found myself using it more when laziness kicked it (I don’t want to go to a locker, only to find that it’s empty. You crazy.)

Crafting isn’t available. However, there is a way to upgrade your weapons with parts found in the world. There are four types of upgrades: firing speed, capacity, spread and firepower. From what I can tell, once a certain upgrade has been installed in a weapon; a second upgrade of the same type cannot be placed in the weapon again. For example, let’s say you placed a firepower upgrade into a shotgun. You cannot modify it again to strengthen the shotgun’s firepower. So once a weapon has all the necessary upgrades it can hold, that’s it. Your brand new shiny weapon is fully upgraded. It’s simple and there is no way of upgrading a weapon further unless you find a stronger version of the weapon.

The weapon diversity is pretty good, ranging from your average pistol, to the more practical shotgun. Additionally, your skill in using a specific type of weapon increases the more you use it. This allows for faster reload, lower recoil, and better stability when aiming (from what I can tell).

My favorite so far is the crossbow. It’s silent and there is a 100% chance of recovering the bolt from the zombie, if you manage to hit the enemy, of course. To my surprise, the game doesn’t flood you with ammo or curatives as I thought it would. Granted, I am playing on Survival Mode (perma-death) so maybe that changes how much items spawn in the world. With me, I have to make each shot count, or else, it’ll be awhile till I find another ammo cache.

That’s where our melee weapons come in. We have a starter Cricket Bat that makes me appreciate the sport in ways I never thought I would. There are other melee weapons but why use them when you can Cricket…ya know? Common sense, people! Besides, there is no way of dropping or storing the starter weapons (I tried) so they waste two valuable slots in your already skimpy backpack space so might as well use them. Speaking of backpack space, they can be increase by finding upgrades for your backpack…yay! Gotta get all them pockets for your dru—food. I mean food.

There are different kinds of zombies friends we can meet in our arduous journey. There are spitting ones, exploding ones, always want to be the center of attention ones, and just plain ‘ole regular cute ones that enjoy a good buffet of humans. Their A.I. are nothing special and can be exploited by finding their “how much can I back up until the zombie turns away, forgetting they were ever pursuing a juicy human” limit. It’s a mouthful but I am working on an alternative title. Unless it’s a horde mode section, you can do this to almost all zombie mobs. I do find the brain eating fellows hilarious sometimes because they will do whatever it takes to get to you if you’re in their aggro range. You see one on the floor above? Don’t worry; they’ll drop down to you so you can beat them to death...again?

I do find the game easy at times, even in Survival Mode. Despite that, I did get cocky and ended up dying at the hands of the exploding monster because I had the audacity to whack it on the head with a bat. Such a diva. From that point, I was a bit cautious and I actually began taking Zombi seriously, which surprised me because I tend to fool around too much in games.

I really do enjoy it, especially survival mode. Normal mode is an alternative if you don’t fancy perma-death situations and if you die in normal mode, the birth of a new survivor occurs and you have some time to gather your belongings from your dead character. The tension does increase in Survival Mode because you don’t want your person to meet a terrible fate, right?

All in all, $20 is a fair price for this game. It’s fun and engaging enough to hold your attention. Buy it if you can.

reviewText:
One of the best scavenge and survive zombie apocalypse games messed up by simple design choices.


Mixed Review:
The game has been plagued by port issues that seem to be resolved. I had to launch in a different setting to get it to work but easy fix. Overall, I love the game BECAUSE of the permadeath. I enjoy submerging myself into the realism of surviving as a character. However, the designers decided to put in mechanics that cheaply rob the player survival. I went through 20 hours of game play only to be blown up by an exploding zombie in tight quarters. It is like the designers decided that a cheap scare was justification in cheating the player of hard working game play. I managed to avoid future deaths only to be confronted in a deathcage scenario towards the end where you're guaranteed to lose a beloved character over and over again no matter what choices you make. The last part of the game is so frustrating because it negates the beauty of the entire permadeath design.

Pros-
-Controls are easy to use (Used 360 wired controller)
-Simple Chivary type melee combat with good gun variety
-You can survive for a long time with smart game play
-Permadeath forces you to take your time
-Sound design

Cons-
-Sometimes it is hard to know what to do next
-Limited inventory
-Certain items cannot be dropped
-Some people will complain about graphics
-If you care about keeping a single character alive all the way through you might be upset at cheap death scenarios

Overall, if you're looking for a good zombie scavenge survive experience on rails this is the game for you. reviewText:
SInce its release back in 2012, I have been wondering why it was taking so long for this game to get ported to PC. Now we know, it's because a great WiiU zombie-survival game, makes a mediocre PC zombie-survival game. Make no mistake, this is a REALLY great zombie game; however, having core mechanics designed around the WiiU's bizarre controls/interface makes it impossible to port very well to other platforms.

On the positive side, it has a somewhat fresh take on zombie survial gameplay. The London setting manages to be both fun and dreary in equal measure. Also, the stakes are raised by giving players only one life. When you die in the game, that character dies and you resume from the perspective of a different character.

Unfortunately, this PC port is not the way to experience it. A lot of the gameplay was conceptualized around the WiiU's controller, which features a second screen and touch interface for that screen. When playing this PC port there are a lot of arbitrary game concepts left over that are either infuriating or downright broken.

If you're looking for a good, PC + FPS + single-player + zombie-survival game then checkout Dying Light. If you are some kind of Zombie game aficionado, then try to find a WiiU to borrow to play this game.

reviewText:
ZombiU is arguably one of the best launch titles for the Wii U. A gritty survival game that managed to make great use out of the extra screen in the form of the Wii U gamepad. Unfortunately, the game sales was considered a flop to Ubisoft, and as such, I don’t think we will see a sequel anytime soon- if at all. ZombiU was one of the few games that made me actually wish that I had a Wii U, and I’m glad that this port was made so that I can play it without purchasing a brand new console.

Now titled Zombi on PC, Xbox One and Ps4- players will find themselves deep inside the heart of London after a zombie outbreak. With your base set up in the London Underground, you must traverse the maze of tunnels to reach other locations for supplies and other mission based challenges. You are able to find a variety of weapons and ammo, such as; Shotguns, Assault Rifles, SMG’s and so on- this is all fine and dandy, but you will end up using your trusty cricket bat more often than not, Shaun of the Dead style. The cricket bat combat can become repetitive for some players.

Combat is not fast paced, if you are going into Zombi expecting a run and gun Left 4 Dead esque game, then Zombi may not be for you. The game has instead gone for a slow style combat- before you can swing your cricket bat, you must first raise the bat using right click to which you can then swing at your foe. Weapons also take a while to reload, so you can definitely feel the tension as a small group of zombies start getting too close as you scramble to find a weapon that is loaded. As mentioned previously, people may find the cricket bat combat a little repetitive, and it is- you do the same swing and when you make contact with a zombie the same animations will appear- at first the skull will crack open and you continue hitting it until it stops moving. There doesn’t really seem to be much of a variety in the zombie combat, sometimes you can take one down with just one strike of your bat, sometimes it takes a few more strikes. I do not find the combat repetitive,  yes I am doing the same thing again and again, but the tense and adrenaline filled moments that I get really do mask up the repetitive motions- and the combat is definitely one of the main things about this game that makes it as tense as it is.

If you find yourself surrounded by zombies, there are a few things you can do. First, throw some flares to distract the zombies, and then throw a grenade to kill the zombies. Secondly, run-  run away as fast as you can to a safer location. If all these fail you then I’m afraid you may be dead, and this is where an interesting game mechanic comes into play.  If at any point you die in the game, that’s it for you, but that doesn’t mean that the game is over and you need to restart from a checkpoint- instead, that character is dead and you get to respawn as a new character. Any items that your previous character had on their person is now gone, unless you get them back. The character you previously were is now a zombie in the world, you can either find and kill them to get your items back, or just leave them. I found this game mechanic to be very interesting, and it definitely made me ponder on whether it not my previous character had enough items of value on them that it was worth tracking them down and killing them.

One of the concerns I had going into Zombi, and concerns that many people had, was how well does the game hold up without the use of the Wii U gamepad. Surprisingly, it holds up pretty darn well. On the gamepad you open barricades by tapping on the screen, on the PC version you just need to mash the Use key. Inventory management is very similar- On the Wii U they showed how all inventory management is done on the gamepads screen as the main game still plays around you. This is the same on the PC version, press Tab to open up your inventory, but be careful as a zombie may get you while you are busy searching through your bag. The Wii U gamepad was also used as the games scanner, a device where you can scan objects to see if there are any items in them, or to other tasks such as hacking.  On the Wii U, you had to hold up the  gamepad to and pretend it was a scanner – so at least on the PC version I feel like less of a fool when I have to use the scanner.

A problem that some of you may have, is that the PC version does use Uplay. I have no problem with this, I would much rather it was just Steam, but it caused me no problems. However, I do understand that many people do have problems with Uplay, so I am just pointing out now that Zombi does use Uplay. Most of the problems will come when you are trying to verify your game code so that Ubisoft knows you have legally purchased it, but if Uplays services are down, you are not going to get very far.

How is the port? Not bad. It maintains a solid framerate throughout the game, but I wouldn’t have expected any better from this game, because there is’t much on show to really lower the framerate. The texture quality isn’t great and everything looks a little rough around the edges- you can easily tell that this was originally a Wii U game, no doubt about it. There seems to be a bug that occurs when you have a controller plugged in but are using a mouse and keyboard, the button prompts will always display as if you were playing on a controller -so if you are not using a controller, make sure you unplug it from your computer.

Zombi is a well done horror game. It has made me jump on a number of occasions from scripted jump sequences and from the atmosphere the game provides.  If you have a Wii U, it may be better to purchase ZombiU instead, but if you do not own that console then you are not missing out on much when you play this version. Despite the game being a little rough around the edges, it is still an experience that I thoroughly enjoyed and I would recommend that everyone gives it a try.

reviewText:
This game would be a very average FPS, but manages to pull off a few good tricks to lift itself above mediocrity.

Most of these tricks owe to a nod to Dark Souls. Levels are nicely interlinked, if linear, but more importantly, the death system helps you get a sense of affinity for your character, and makes you want to survive and plan rather than quickload. Death results in you spawning as another randomly generated survivor, with a need to hunt down your previously zombified self if you want to reclaim your backpack. The game puts some effort into giving each new survivor a unique character, from their own outfit and gender down to an ID card with their age, occupation, and stat tracking of how long they've survived and their individual score. As a result, you tend to get the same involvement as with a squad member in X-COM - after you've struggled through a few hours as the same character, you really want to see how long you can last.

It's important the game generates tension this way, since combat itself is fairly simplistic and where the similarities with Dark Souls end. For a large part of the game the default cricket bat will serve you well, to the extent that guns are largely unneccessary. This has a knock-on effect of you saving ammo to the point it's scarcity isn't an issue in the later stages of the game, which is a shame. This isn't a hard game, but the desire to stay alive rather than save-zerg helps maintain suspense, and it is certainly possible to meet a swift end if you make a mistake.

Visually, the game has some interesting locations, and whilst it's not going to be picking up any awards for next-gen graphics or push a high-end PC to its limits, it looks suitably atmospheric. I've seen some reports of crashing, but on my vanilla rig (i7/9700) I've yet to experience one. The audio gets the job done, with the usual zombie moans alerting the player and some good player voice acting reflecting their terror after caving in a zombie's head.

In terms of the negatives, a uPlay account being needed is an obvious one, but not too much of a pain to set up if you don't have one already. The plot is rather scattered and implausible, with your character unswervingly doing what they're told even if it flies in the face of common sense or survival instinct, and not helped by the questions raised by the player character changing but the NPCs treating them as the same person. Given the alternative of a single character with a quicksave/load function, though, it's a worthwhile tradeoff. Multiplayer was dropped for the port, but it wasn't that great in the first place, and there are many better multiplayer zombie games out there.

This is basically a solid 20 hours or so of atmospheric, single-player FPS gaming. Not a AAA title, but a worthwhile experience at the price tag.

reviewText:
Ok I bought this knowing it is a PC port but I fancied a game set in London rather than Moscow, New York or Chernorus.

The game adapts pretty well to PC in terms of graphics and controls although if you're a keyboard player a little remapping is required to get it comfortable and user friendly. Sound is good as are the graphics, and the atmosphere created is spot on.

Gameplay - linear and managed. If you die (which I did a lot) you respawn back at base and can then work your way back to where you were quite quickly. There's a bit of problem solving but you're spoon fed by a voice in your ear, the Prepper. It's not in the league of Dinocrisis where you really did have to use your brains - but guess with walkthroughs out there on the www this is quite an old fashioned view for me to have anyway.

Combat - simple, unsatisfyingly simple. Dead Island set the standard for combat in my opinion. In Zombi - LMB = shove with weapon, RMB = raise weapon, then LMB again = strike with weapon, Not very effective and there are no other strikes etc to play with.

Reason for not recommending the game - none of the above issues would have put me off. What makes me say don't buy this game for PC is that the game is heavily bugged with crash to desk top when your character gets back to the area where they last died. This is frequent and problematic. There is no official fix coming that I know of, and many of the player developed work arounds seen on Steam relate more to wishful thinking than actual fact, and don't seem to work for each and every player.

Additionally, having asked for a refund on the basis that the game isn't fit for PC release, Steam have declined as I have played 8 hours. Seeing that I have only been affected by the bugs in the last hour of my gameplay this is not a very happy outcome. My advice is - if you're in doubt about whether it will work on your PC, don't buy it, as you may not be able to get a refund.

EDIT: it seems the game devs have now debugged the issues that led to constant crashes - which is good. However, I am still dissatisfied with the Steam response re the request for a refund. Having carried on playing, the game has got boring, mainly becasue of the game play and strategy which is very very linear and micromanaged, plus the introduction of sudden death explodng zombies. There's no real sense of fun or exploration - just follow the route map, swing the bat and occasionally get blown up.

Finally decided to quit and uninstall when I was kidnapped and you are then forced to play a minigame of sorts in an arena to move on and I just cannot be arsed. If you're a sugar fuelled teen with lightining reflexes you'd possibly not mind, but after a  long day at work I don't care for it.

I like the game but the things I don't like about it really hack me off. I think that many players might like the gameplay and the Englishness of it though so not a conclsuive thumbs down, 6/10.

reviewText:
My two cents after only two hours of play, yes two hours. Sorry.

The first hurdle is to acquire a uPlay account. Easy enough however you cannot launch the game without one. You also cannot launch the game without steam so, you need two (2) seperate DRM sources to play one game. uPlay also cannot be closed or even placed into a semi sleep state and will constantly demand resources while it loads your uPlay page with randomly generated information while it runs in the background taking up resources. This on top of steam also running.

The options can be a bit confusing but you can stumble your way through them easily enough, the FOV slider doesnt seem very useful though.

Its a precursor for another more amazing game called Alien Isolation. Same simple crafting system, find recipy upgrade item. Same way to duck into and out of things. However there are massive differences which need to be noted. The first of which is the complete lack of a stealth system or even a crouch ability. In a zombie game? No way to duck or hide or anything? its run and block a door wait for the zeds to file in one at a time kill them and thats it? Yes that it literally it. And you will do this repeatedly over and over and over and over and over. If you are any kind of decent gamer you will find you have little to no need for ammo as the cricket bat is deadly enough with its rng OHK abilities and no need to run around to try and reload, just hold right mouse and wham your way through that horde.

There are places where you will die, and die needlessly as the game forces you into certain, unavoidable animations. For one, when you enter water that is higher than knee deep, your character will lift up his pack, which btw only has 12 slots, making for lots and lots of return trips to your base to simply store loot in your whopping 14 slot storage case, which you can only find at your base despite there being smaller outposts scattered around areas, but I am getting off track here. Your character will enter these unavoidable animations and will take their sweet time exiting them even in the face of a zombie breathing down your neck, and this has caused me great distress. losing a high level survivor to something so ridiculously unecessary really spoiled the game for me.

Also, you will not be able to complete hard mode as a female survivor, as you will always start as a male, because the first survivor in the opening cut scenes is male, so yeah, lol ubisoft gg. i guess it was too hard to make the opening survivor cloaked in some way so you wouldnt be able to tell sex, and you could pick sex once you reach the first hideout section, but w/e's not a huge issue for some, just a few steps backwards in a unisex gaming world today.

Randomly, either after entering or exiting an area, dying, sleeping (which is the only way to save and there are zero checkpoints) your inventory will become completely unresponsive forcing you to shut the game down entirely then jump back through the uPlay hoops to get it back running again. Sometimes randomly, certain inv items will becomes locked for reasons, forcing you again to quit the game and restart it to fix the issue. Which means, lol if you are neck deep into a mission, you need to run to the closest shortcut, which can be as close as the very start of a level, forcing you to run all the way back, if that is even possible, which sometimes it isnt, just to save progress so you can fix your inv issues.

Some good points was, this reminded me of a very basic alien isolation, it could have used a ♥♥♥♥♥on more depth, but hey, it was fun for two hours, then it got extremely repetative extremely quickly. And if you are the type who likes to explore around, loot everything you can etc., forget it, this is a very much on rails game with everything from not being able to jump over the smallest obstacles, because you literally cannot jump unless prompted to, to needing c4 of all things to get that one energy drink just out of reach. Also about 70% of all containers will be disappointly empty, so unless its a large cache or clearly ammo, which you dont need, you will be rushing through areas quickly, completely ignoring lootable objects.

I wish I could recommend this game but it simply does not bring enough to the table to justify the $20 price tag. if it goes onsale for maybe $5-$10 I maybe will pick it back up to finish but for now, definately look elsewhere for a good $20 bang for your buck.

reviewText:
Before the WiiU launched, Zombiu was hotly tipped to be its first killer app, and whether you agree with that or not, it made a big impact upon its release. Critics and players alike were divided though, with many calling it “ugly”, “slow” and “repetitive”. Much noise was made around its novel use of the gamepad as a map and inventory screen, drawing your eyes away from any lurking zombies approaching on the TV. Yet, even the game’s harshest critics conceded that there was something special lurking beneath ZombiU’s rotting facade. But what is ZombiU without Nintendo’s unconventional controller? Zombi, as it is now known, plays the same as before but it is, arguably, all the better for having dropped the “U” from its name.

For all intents and purposes Zombi is the same game you can pick up for a fiver on WiiU, with the exception of a few changes. Combat is still clunky and dull, but a few new melee weapons thrown into the mix, and a slight attack speed increase. Graphically, the game is as dated as ever, with big ugly textures and asset repetition being commonplace. Multiplayer features have been ripped right out as well, leaving you with just the single player campaign to fight through. So, why then, is Zombi still so appealing, even with its many imperfections and cutbacks?

Playing as a lone survivor you’ll sneak around the derelict streets of London, while they are teaming with infected. Guided by “The Prepper” – a cynical ex-military survivor – you’ll work your way across the city from the underground to Buckingham Palace, all in a bid to stay alive, and escape to safety.

Survival is your focus in Zombi, and you’ll find plenty of equipment scattered across London. You can carry a limited number of items around with you in your bug out bag (B.O.B); a bag that holds your food, first aid kits and weapons. And here’s where things get interesting. If you get overwhelmed by the undead you’ll re-spawn in the underground as a new survivor – and you’ll need to get all of your old equipment back. To do so you’ll have to track down your previous character, cave their head in and make off with your loot. Lovely.

Once you’ve got your stuff back you’re free to pick up where you left off, before your previous survivor had their brains scooped out. You could argue that Zombi does little to endear you to your character, perhaps subtracting from, what is otherwise, an immersive game. You never really learn much about them, except for some intro text every time you re-spawn, so there’s no real personal connection tying you to the game.

As previously mentioned, Zombi is a little rough around the edges in the graphics department, but it still manages to succeed in creating a foreboding atmosphere. Expert use of lighting, shade and audio serves as proof that graphical fidelity comes second to well-designed environments and sound. This is a game where you’ll tentatively turn corners, flash your torch every few steps, and stop to listen for nearby undead. Paranoia becomes an asset rather than a burden, leading you to decapitate already dead enemies, look behind yourself every few seconds, and take the long way around to avoid encounters.

Zombi’s combat is never the focal point, and neither it should be because it’s rubbish. The game’s main appeal lays in its ability to mess with your head, make you preempt things and expect the unexpected. Outright scares are sparsely dotted throughout the game, evoking panic and disorientation at the worst possible times. Zombi doesn’t want you to win, and that’s why it’s so great.

The majority of horror games I’ve played simply try too hard to evoke a reaction from the player, but Zombi is different. It’s all too happy to let you become comfortable with your surroundings. It lets you become sloppy and the pounces on you with expert precision.

Although it’s far from perfect, as an original IP Zombi is among some of the better games and deserves a second chance to live.

Temper your expectations,  close the curtains and lose your head in its undead fantasy.

reviewText:
I did not play the original Wii version so I cannot compare it to the original.  The PC version, however, is generally disppointing.  The game does get some things right, namely the moody and atmospheric setting, the music, and the jump scares.  The graphics, however are just not up to the current standard.

The game world is quite small and you'll find yourself going over the same ground time and time again.  In many cases, there are areas that simply cannot be accessed until you aquire the right item or upgrade (and for which there is no clue or hint of where it might be found), which forces you to go back to areas you've already visited.

The weapons you can aquire in the game are terribly underpowered and ammunition is extremely rare, which limits their effectiveness even more.  You'll find yourself using your trusty cricket bat 90% of the time and simply bludgeoning zombies over and over again until they die.

Speaking of which, every time your character dies, you respawn at the original location without any of the items you have found.  Your only choice is to go back to where you died, kill your former self and recover your items, or forget it completely and start with no items.  After a while, I didn't bother picking up any of the advanced weapons (shotguns, assault rifles, etc), since you only get enough ammo to ensure that they run out in the middle of fight.

The game can only be saved from certain locations and only if you have discovered them

All in all, I really like the atmosphere and the feel" of the gameworld

My first playthrough of the game was on the Wii U, I died about 2 hours in, tried retrieving my items with my second survivor and died because they weren't equiped properly enough to deal with the amount of Zombies in the area my initial survivor died. Survivor two went down and there went all of my equipment. I quit and never played the game again.

The game's hit PC now and I don't have to muddle about with a Gamepad or twin-stick FPS controls, so I gave the game another shot. I came to find the game's semi-permadeath gameplay is still incredibly awful.

My first go around I made good time, in about 30 minutes I was in the same spot I managed to get to on the WiiU; fantastic, having a keyboard+mouse makes a world of difference. However, over an hour later I came to find Zombies with oxygen tanks who in my findings blew up when I shot them, cool, let me crack them over the head with my cricket bat and... Boom. I explode. My first survivor is dead. Great. Now I have to trek back to my corpse and get my supplies.

I did that via the sewer tunnel fast-travel system in a couple minutes and got my things back. Around an hour after that I step on a mine and my second survivor is dead but it's my fault, so screw it, except that my corpse is nowhere to be found and all of my stuff is gone for good. Why? No idea.

At this point I'm at the end of the game, I'm running out of a building while an alarm wails and I'm getting attacked left and right. Things start taking a turn for the worst and I die. At this point I just want to finish the game and never play it again but it doesn't want to let me do so. My new survivor has nothing, not even the tools to scan open the door that'll let me use the fast travel tunnels. I'm going to have to get my ♥♥♥ all the way back to the end game with a survivor that has the bare minimum of supplies. I gave it a shot, ran into a room and proceeded to get overwhelmed by 6 or so zombies that there was no way in hell to deal with.

Screw it, uninstall.

Other than that the game looks pretty aged and the level design is awful, everything is windy and maze-like with very little that is destinguishable. Also, more than half of the game takes place in the sewer system. Every area in England is apparently only connected by sewer systems. Also the sewers suffer from Halo levels of copy-and-paste level design, you'll see the same areas over and over when you're in the sewers you're going to wonder if you're going in circles. It's horrible. There's also a lot of back tracking through the sewers, it's awful.

The sound/gun mechanics are great and this could of been a really good title but it's definitely not worth it.

reviewText:
The game is good, even great at times, with great atmosphere and gameplay that is just engaging enough to keep you slogging through the repetitive melee. Sound design and music are spot on, and I really appreciated all the little touches put into the survivor characters to make each one feel pretty unique. However the game is buggy - and these bugs are most pronounced when you die for something that you didn't deserve (say, clipping through the floor of an elevator and falling to your death, or clipping off a ladder and falling to your death - lots of falling to your death) and you lose a character that you may have put alot of time into. The game is just about good enough to keep you wanting more in the face of these really frustrating problems... until you factor in uplay.

Uplay is a pile of filth, not only because the very idea of it being forced on you is abusive but because it is a grossly incompetent service. The game failed to launch at least half of the time and would occaisionally crash back to desktop, but the real cherry on top, the real reason I am even writing this review, is when uplay stops everything to say you need to re-enter your activation code to bring the game up but then says the code you enter is already in use (because you entered it when you initially started the game) and then just leaves you stranded with a game you can no longer open. It very cheerfully tells you that your account has already used this code and to please access your games from your library, but when you go to your library to open the game, it pops back up with the enter activation code window and the whole process becomes a loop - which ends with uplay suspending your account if you try to enter your valid code enough times. Sure, you could get in touch with uplay to resolve the issue, even though there is no direction from uplay itself about how to do this, but at this point the only thing I want to express to uplay is disgust.

Decent game made unplayable and a waste of time by a shambolic, embaressingly inept and wholly unnecessary service. Save your money for something that you will actually own after purchasing.

reviewText:
I'm just a casual gamer, but I thought the horror aspect of the game hit right on. The fact that dying means the permanent end for the character makes the game much more intense. I liked the combat a lot. It is a little terrifying because there's so much noise while fighting one zombie that you might not notice another sneaking up behind you. All in all, its a worthy puchase for any zombie fan, as long as the game works.

I played until the second mission when my first character died. The game now crashes everytime the second character goes into that area. Apparently this is a very common issue. There's not much help for it online, but the 2-3 webpages I found had various solutions that ended up not working for my issue. So I'm debating if I'll restart the game and try to unlock the sewer entrance to buckingham palace and see if that fixes the issue, or if I'll just stop playing altogether. Either way, only get this game if you're mentally prepared to eat the cost of an unplayable game.

There was a lot of room for improvement on the functional part of the game also. The only information it gives you about the characters is a name, occupation, and their looks. It would've been a whole new ball game if you could pick one out of a handful of possible survivors each time you need a new one, do basic customization of their clothes the longer they were alive, and possibly get some back story on them. Just small things like that to increase the players attachment to certain characters, increasing the tension and fear that they'll die. I think the permanent death of characters was what really set this game apart from other zombie survival games, but it should've been emphasized more. I also wish I could switch the cricket bat out for other melee weapons. I found the shovel that had better damage and range, but it had to take up a separate pack spot, even though it made the cricket bat obsolete.

reviewText:
Needs Work

I love zombie games...of all sorts.  Left4Dead, Dying Light, State of Decay, Dead State, Dead Rising, etc, etc.  So when I heard ZombiU (a game I had never played) was coming out on other consoles after being a WiiU exclusive, I was excited, and bought it on day one.  I had heard mixed things, but it had my interest, and I was hoping it would be something fun.

Instead the overall product is underwhelming and unpolished.  My first red flag went up when I saw that the cutscenes were extremely muddy and pixelated, like something out of the old PS1 days.  During game play, glitches abound.  Hits often don't register, prompts to execute zombies while on the floor are ignored, and things like that.

Then the game crashed right at a cutscene on the top of the London tower.  Disgusted, I decided to take a break from it.  The next day when I decided to try again, apparently the crash completely deleted my game save and I was faced with starting over the whole lackluster process again.  I said no.  I'll try and see if I can get a refund even though I'm beyond the playtime cap.  It's worth a try, right?  Better that than slogging through all that again.  So, no, I wouldn't recommend it until a patch or two comes out.

To make a long story short: you are dead because of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ programming.

I just would not recommed zombi, at least not in its current state. I could complain that the graphics are mediocre or that the game is so weird that they think that if England suffered a zombie apocalypse then our first reaction is to vist the monarchy. Ignoring them issues the game it's self is quite boring. The gameplay remindes me of Dead Island where it's just very cluncky, slow and dull. The gun play works fine but since your at limited ammo and you don't want to attract noise, its not worth the risk so you end up playing constent wack a mole with your trusty cricket bat against the zombies. The constent moaning as you hit the zombies heads almost gets annoying and it takes so many hits, please if your going to make a sequal, make a range of weapons to bash the zombies heads with to make the combat less tedious.

However, the whole idea of the game is acually great and I think it deserves another shot. The dark murky atmostphere did honestly bring me the chills and scared me at times. The games permerdeath system is really unique. When you die, you lose all your supplies and if you want them back then you need to kill the zombie version of old you. Its acually amazing how you almost grow a emotional attachment to your character after a while and your gutted to see him or her die not just because of the suppies but the person itself is a loss.

I think that ubisoft should give Stright Right another shot at making this better (making a sequal). A better combat, better graphics and less 'WiiU'ness would possible make this one of the best zombie horror game since resident evil. Sadly though, this is not something i would recommend buying unless you are just doing it to ask for a sequal.

reviewText: I bought this on Steam release despite owning and never playing it on the WiiU... mostly just because I was shocked that they didn't try to charge more than $20 and because they confirmed a FOV slider. Of course I promptly left it on the pile just like I did with the original release until now. I definitely feel bad for doing that since the game is just as cool as it's fans say it is. The developers did a really smart job of borrowing some Souls game design and wrapping it into a slow-paced zombie survival horror game. While the run back to regain your weapons and supplies isn't quite as punishing as the Souls games, a death does feel more fittingly punishing than just a checkpoint restart. The level design is surprisingly clever and does a really nice job of feeling just layered enough to make revisits to areas interesting (being able to mark locked doors on the map is really handy). The combat feels just the right level of clunky. The melee weapons are pretty poor for mobs, while the guns feel slow and weak unless you nail headshots consistently. The balance works well and keeps each engagement interesting as you weigh your options. I loved the mood of the game too. It's aggressively British and the fog and grime help out the weaker aspects of the visuals.\n\nVerdict: Give it a shot.

reviewText: Zombi was very mediocre. I am big fan of the zombie adventure genre ala Resident Evil so I wasn't completely bored by it, but it just doesn't do anything to generate much excitement throughout the campaign. There is a part where you go to a day care center and are introduced to a new enemy type. This part was really creepy and well done, but it's only a very small part of the game that is completely unscary otherwise. The graphics look really flat. Zombi was a WiiU launch title and it looks like there was no visual enchancements done over that version.  I found the world map to be confusing to navigate. The map is split up into sections and each section is typically connected to at least a couple of  other sections, but the map isn't very clear on how to get from one section to the next. The different sections don't look very distict from one another or even visually interesting either. Essentially, there are city streets  with garbage dumped everywhere and there are sewers.  Also, at the end of the game a lot of the paths are closed off so to get to where you need to go, a huge portion needs to be traversed. I found this to be frustrating especially considering the frequently confusing terrain layout. Combat wasn't very engaging. It all came across like a watered-down version of combat in Dead Island.

reviewText: I bought this on Steam release despite owning and never playing it on the WiiU... mostly just because I was shocked that they didn't try to charge more than $20 and because they confirmed a FOV slider. Of course I promptly left it on the pile just like I did with the original release until now. I definitely feel bad for doing that since the game is just as cool as it's fans say it is. The developers did a really smart job of borrowing some Souls game design and wrapping it into a slow-paced zombie survival horror game. While the run back to regain your weapons and supplies isn't quite as punishing as the Souls games, a death does feel more fittingly punishing than just a checkpoint restart. The level design is surprisingly clever and does a really nice job of feeling just layered enough to make revisits to areas interesting (being able to mark locked doors on the map is really handy). The combat feels just the right level of clunky. The melee weapons are pretty poor for mobs, while the guns feel slow and weak unless you nail headshots consistently. The balance works well and keeps each engagement interesting as you weigh your options. I loved the mood of the game too. It's aggressively British and the fog and grime help out the weaker aspects of the visuals.\n\nVerdict: Give it a shot.
